subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: Of course NURSE is spelled with /yr/, which represents /3r/. Consider the phrase arrest Ernie . It s arrest we re talking about. John Cowan earlier pointed
messageBody:
Of course NURSE is spelled with /yr/, which represents /3r/. Consider
the phrase "arrest Ernie". It's "arrest" we're talking about. John
Cowan earlier pointed out that in his accent both words begin with
/3r/. For him, and for many other Americans, there is no issue here.

Ted

On Dec 4, 2007 1:48 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
> Yes, but only for some accents (mine included). I'll restate my
> earlier conclusion based on focused attention on /yr/ in my own
> reading and writing: I think this is a minor issue that is quickly
> overcome with a little practice. Given that many people will not have
> this issue at all, I think it does not warrant any change in usage.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> I don't think that's the case. Both dictionary.com, and in my Longman
> dictionary, list words like NURSE spelled with /3r/. Both dictionaries
> represent the majority of American speakers. The Cambridge dictionary lists
> it the same way. So most people will have this issue. Yes, we can overcome
> the ambiguity with practice, but then the spelling replicates the mistakes
> in TO, in which we have to learn by context what sounds letters make, rather
> than have one unambiguous representation.
>
>
> Paul
>
>
>
